name: Raj Panjabi
text: We will be short 18 million health workers by 2030. Let us be mindful that this would mean that we will miss out on 18 million opportunities for dignified employment. We cannot, you cannot let this happen. @MaEllenSirleaf @DrTedros #UNGA74

name: Raj Panjabi
text: The project leverages smartphones to modernize training of thousands of rural community & frontline health workers, with instructional videos & self-quizzes in areas like childhood malaria treatment & diagnosing malnutrition in the palms of their hands. Keep on, Nowai, keep on.

name: Raj Panjabi
text: Today, Nowai works with @LastMileHealth on our Liberia and Community Health Academy teams, working with partners to coordinate a continuing clinical education project in support of Liberia's Ministry of Health.

name: Raj Panjabi
text: On one of her first nights at the clinic, Nowai remembers being mentored by the local midwife to successfully deliver twins. The twins and their mother survived. She is now paying forward the lessons she once learned.

name: Raj Panjabi
text: Upon graduation, her first assignment was in a community clinic in an off-road, off-grid, off-network rural community in Bong. The assignment was challenging. Not only did Nowai have to lead the clinic, she had to rebuild it after the war left it abandoned for nearly two decades.

name: Raj Panjabi
text: Nowai was trained as a nurse at Cuttington in Liberia's Bong County. When our civil war displaced her class and teachers, threatening to disrupt her education, Nowai persisted.

name: Raj Panjabi
text: I just had an inspiring lunch with Nowai Gray, an extraordinary clinical educator and leader @lastmilehealth. See thread to learn about her work to bring health care within reach of every last child and family in Liberia.//t.co/tsMBTyrnL8

name: Raj Panjabi
text: I changed this as a community health worker. I work with my nurse supervisor to refer women to the clinic for family planning services. Now, many of the women in my community are taking contraceptives and the birth rate is only 1-2 pregnancies per year.

name: Raj Panjabi
text: As small as my community is, there used to be about 6-7 pregnancies every year. The moms and their babies were not healthy and some were dying because they were having complications.

name: Raj Panjabi
text: The Ministry of Health recognizes the importance of my work and they make sure I am trained, supplied, supervised, and paid. - Ruth Tarr, community health worker from Rivercess in Liberia #astana2018//t.co/G9GmHv3FwS
